author: By Michael Levenson
title: 4 Skiers Killed in Avalanche in Utah, Officials Say
description: It was the third such deadly episode in days and the deadliest avalanche in the United States since May 2014, according to the authorities.
content: Four backcountry skiers were killed on Saturday in an avalanche in Utah, the police said. It was the deadliest avalanche in the United States since May 2014, when six climbers were killed on Mount Rainier in Washington, according to the Colorado Avalanche Information Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Giang
title: 60 Black health experts urge Black Americans to get vaccinated.
description: Black Americans are being killed by Covid-19 at 1.5 times the rate of white Americans, yet many Black people are hesitant to line up for a vaccine.
content: Black Americans are being killed by Covid-19 at 1.5 times the rate of white Americans, yet many Black people are hesitant to line up for a vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José María León Cabrera, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Ecuador’s Presidential Vote Heads to a Runoff
description: A leftist economist, the protégé of a populist past president, Rafael Correa, was the top vote-getter. Which opponent he will face in April appeared uncertain.
content: QUITO, Ecuador — Ecuadoreans are headed for a runoff presidential election following a vote Sunday in which a leftist economist drew the most votes, but not enough to secure an outright victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Virus Variant First Found in Britain Now Spreading Rapidly in U.S.
description: A new study bolsters the prediction by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that the so-called B.1.1.7 variant will dominate Covid-19 cases by March.
content: A more contagious variant of the coronavirus first found in Britain is spreading rapidly in the United States, doubling roughly every 10 days, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Explore the History of Jazz and Celebrate the Lunar New Year
description: This week, learn about the African-American chefs who supported the White House kitchen, listen to a family-friendly concert or attend a poetry reading.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Amanda Gorman is the first poet to perform for the Super Bowl.
description: In her short but already momentous career, the 22-year-old poet Amanda Gorman has accomplished a stunning series of firsts. At 19, she became the country’s first Youth Poet Laureate. Last month, when she recited her poem, “The Hill We Climb,” at President Biden’s inauguration, she became the youngest inaugural poet in American history. And on Sunday, she became the first poet ever to perform for the Super Bowl.
content: In her short but already momentous career, the 22-year-old poet Amanda Gorman has accomplished a stunning series of firsts. At 19, she became the country’s first Youth Poet Laureate. Last month, when she recited her poem, “The Hill We Climb,” at President Biden’s inauguration, she became the youngest inaugural poet in American history. And on Sunday, she became the first poet ever to perform for the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Leon Spinks, Boxer Who Took Ali’s Crown and Lost It, Dies at 67
description: He was an Olympic champion with few pro fights under his belt when he surprised the world by beating the champ in 1978. Things did not go smoothly after that.
content: Leon Spinks, who scored one of boxing’s greatest upsets when he defeated Muhammad Ali to capture the heavyweight championship in February 1978, but lost his crown in a rematch seven months later and never again found glory in the ring, died on Friday night in Henderson, Nev. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas A. LaVeist and Georges C. Benjamin
title: 60 Black Health Experts Urge Black Americans to Get Vaccinated
description: Disinformation has pervaded social media and is an assault on our people.
content: Our country is facing a public health crisis on a level not experienced for more than 100 years. It should be reasonable to expect that all citizens can rely on their government and health institutions to protect them. But for many Black Americans, trust in the government does not come easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The choices of fans have public health implications.
description: Common sense dictates that bringing together 25,000 people during a pandemic could lead to more coronavirus infections, and the Super Bowl in Tampa, Fla., is no exception. But trying to pin down how many infections could stem from this event has frustrated scientists because contact tracing is often spotty, even more so when fans after Sunday’s game return to their homes in all corners of the country.
content: Common sense dictates that bringing together 25,000 people during a pandemic could lead to more coronavirus infections, and the Super Bowl in Tampa, Fla., is no exception. But trying to pin down how many infections could stem from this event has frustrated scientists because contact tracing is often spotty, even more so when fans after Sunday’s game return to their homes in all corners of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Beyond ‘Black Panther’: Afrofuturism Is Booming in Comics
description: A bumper crop of graphic novels and comic books melds African culture and science fiction, with influences as wide-ranging as space travel, Caribbean folklore and Janelle Monáe.
content: When Barack Obama was elected president in 2008, it struck the author and illustrator John Jennings as so unprecedented, such a break from American history, that it was like an event from some far-flung future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Protesters Rally Across Myanmar, Defying Coup and Risking Crackdown
description: Hundreds of thousands of people marched in cities and towns nationwide nearly a week after the military took back power. It has met demonstrations with deadly force in the past.
content: People marched through Monywa, in the heart of Myanmar, and Mawlamyine, on the eastern coast, demanding an end to military rule. They refused to disperse in the casino town of Myawaddy, even when the police fired warning shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Ivor Prickett
title: Years After a Massacre, Yazidis Finally Bury Their Loved Ones
description: The bodies of 103 men and boys killed in 2014 were recovered from a mass grave and returned to a shattered community that still fears for its future.
content: KOJO, Iraq — They had waited years to bury the remains of their husbands, sons and brothers. Cradling fresh earth draped in Iraqi flags, the Yazidi women called out as if their loved ones could still hear them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Spurning Calls to Resign, Liz Cheney Says G.O.P. Must Move Past Trump
description: Ms. Cheney, having fended off a challenge to her House leadership role, was defiant in defending her impeachment vote and called for Republicans to be “the party of truth.”
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming waded deeper into Republicans’ identity crisis on Sunday, warning her party on the eve of a Senate impeachment trial not to “look past” former President Donald J. Trump’s role in stoking a violent attack on the Capitol and a culture of conspiracy roosting among their ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: The Chiefs enter the field to the sound of the tomahawk chop.
description: The Kansas City Chiefs have banned fans from wearing Native American headdresses at Arrowhead Stadium, but fans continue to swing their arms in a tomahawk chop to celebrate their team’s success on the field. They did it again as the team ran onto the field Sunday.
content: The Kansas City Chiefs have banned fans from wearing Native American headdresses at Arrowhead Stadium, but fans continue to swing their arms in a tomahawk chop to celebrate their team’s success on the field. They did it again as the team ran onto the field Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Walking With My Mother, I Always Hung on Tightly to Her Hand’
description: Growing up in College Point, a downstairs neighbor’s welcome noise and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Chicago Teachers Tentatively Agree to Return to Classrooms
description: If approved, the deal would avert a strike and allow some students to receive in-person instruction starting this week.
content: The Chicago Teachers Union has reached a tentative deal with Mayor Lori Lightfoot to partially reopen the city’s schools for in-person classes starting this week, the mayor announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Einsteinium Is Mysterious. Scientists Have Unlocked Some of Its Secrets.
description: Number 99 on the periodic table does not occur naturally and is difficult to make and store, challenging researchers who want to study it.
content: Einsteinium is an element with a famous name that almost no one has heard of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Mulcahy
title: Why Were So Many Stettheimer Art Works Up for Sale? Not All Were Real
description: Five works by the dazzling and seldom-seen painter Florine Stettheimer emerged on the market in 2020. But some stood on shaky ground.
content: Years can pass without work by the singular modernist Florine Stettheimer (1871-1944) appearing on the art market. Her estate went mostly to museums and universities. Which made 2020 a banner year, with five pieces popping up at auction houses and galleries in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Lost: A Golden Flute on a Train. Found: Faith in Others.
description: Donald Rabin, 23, searched for days for his $22,000 flute, which he left on a Chicago train during a visit.
content: Donald Rabin carefully placed his flute made of silver and 18-karat gold next to him on a Chicago train.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 7, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 7, 2021.
content: An article on Page 12 about whether showrunners will incorporate the pandemic into new seasons misidentifies the TV network that broadcasts the legal series “All Rise.” It is CBS, not ABC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips, Taylor Lorenz, Tara Siegel Bernard and Gillian Friedman
title: The Hopes That Rose and Fell With GameStop
description: Fueled by amateur traders and online enthusiasm, the struggling retailer’s shares took investors on a ride like no other. For them, it ended in different ways, including apathy, defiance and regret.
content: Some wanted to be on the front lines of a revolution. Some wanted to be rich. And by the end of a wild two-week ride where fortunes were made and lost, some just hoped they’d be able to pay their rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Impeachment, Housing Crisis, Super Bowl LV: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Turned Back by Italy, Migrants Face Perilous Winter in Balkans
description: Advocacy groups and legislators say a practice of informal deportations violates Italian, European Union and international laws. At least one court in Rome agreed.
content: ROME — To escape persecution in his homeland, a 27-year-old Pakistani man walked over mountains and through woods on an arduous 18-month journey across Bosnia, Croatia and Slovenia until he finally reached the Italian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Meme Stock Bubble Bursts
description: As the GameStop bubble burst, the market had its best rally in months.
content: Happy Super Bowl Sunday. Here are the top business stories to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Brain Within the Brain of a Rising Tennis Queen
description: Iga Swiatek of Poland came out of nowhere to win the French Open in October. A sports psychologist was with her all the way.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — In October, a teenager from Poland, Iga Swiatek, stunned the tennis world when she came out of nowhere to win the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Strong Trump Supporters Picked to Head Michigan Republican Party
description: The state’s selection of party chair and vice chair hinged in large part on who was most loyal to the former president.
content: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich. — Ron Weiser, a wealthy real estate developer from Ann Arbor, was elected chair of the Michigan Republican Party on Saturday, bringing along a vice chair who has caused consternation among some factions of the party because of her fierce support of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 8, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Its Musicians Are Out of Work, but the Met Is Streaming
description: Anna Netrebko sang a recital live from Vienna as the opera company and its unions remain in a standoff.
content: The Metropolitan Opera rang in 2020 auspiciously, with a Puccini gala featuring Anna Netrebko, the company’s reigning diva.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: The Tulsa Massacre, Remembered by Those Who Survived
description: “Goin’ Back to T-Town,” the 1993 PBS documentary about the mass murder of a city’s Black residents and the destruction of their community, returns.
content: PBS has reached into its vault and retrieved “Goin’ Back to T-Town,” a 1993 “American Experience” documentary whose broadcast Monday night is doubly timely. It marks the 100th anniversary later this year of the Tulsa massacre, the deadly and massively destructive race riot that remained little known when the film was made but lately has re-emerged as a supremely ugly scar on the American conscience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘Scenter’ of the Face
description: Portia Lundie makes their debut in the daily New York Times Crossword.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Portia Lundie has constructed Midi-size puzzles for the New York Times Crossword app, but this is their debut in the dailies. (Ms. Lundie’s pronoun preferences are “she” and the singular “they.” For additional comments, please see the end of this column.) For those who are unfamiliar with Midis, those are 9x9 crosswords that are meant to be a quicker solve than the Daily (generally 15x15 or larger), but not as quick as the Mini (generally 5x5).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Throws a Super Bowl Party With Host Dan Levy
description: Phoebe Bridgers crushes it as musical guest and  Eugene Levy makes a Covid-era cameo to watch his son and “Schitt’s Creek” co-star host.
content: On the night before the Super Bowl, “Saturday Night Live” mostly set aside its political satire and celebrity impersonations to pay satirical homage to the healing power of sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Knicks Nearing Trade for Derrick Rose
description: Rose, a former All-Star guard with the Detroit Pistons, last played for the Knicks in the 2016-17 season. He has been one of the N.B.A.’s best bench scorers this season at 14.2 points per game.
content: The Knicks are finalizing a trade to reacquire the former N.B.A. All-Star guard Derrick Rose from the Detroit Pistons, according to two people briefed on the transaction. The deal will reunite Rose with Tom Thibodeau, who coached Rose in Minnesota and Chicago and now leads the Knicks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chanel Miller
title: When Silver Linings Don’t Cut It, Honesty Helps
description: When Suleika Jaouad was 22, she learned she had leukemia. In her memoir, “Between Two Kingdoms,” she looks back on what got her through.
content: BETWEEN TWO KINGDOMSA Memoir of a Life InterruptedBy Suleika Jaouad
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France’s Latest Covid Measure: Letting Workers Eat at Their Desks
description: The coronavirus pandemic has already upended eating habits in a country where the table is a sacred space. Now it is taking its toll on a symbol of work-life balance.
content: PARIS — Eating habits are as good a guide to France as any, and they are about to undergo a radical change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: A Century Ago, White Protestant Extremism Marched on Washington
description: Kelly J. Baker is a writer and scholar of the Ku Klux Klan in the 1920s. She sees frightening similarities between that culture and the violence at the Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: In the weeks following the attack on the Capitol, many Americans have argued over whether the violence was a singular event or an outcome of deeper forces. Voters, Congress and a former president are clashing over who is to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: The Women Who Paved the Way for Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: She’s the latest descendant in a lineage of Republican women who embrace a boffo radicalism.
content: When I was coming of age as a journalist, it was an article of faith — and political science — that female Republican politicians subdued their party’s excesses. It was a measurable phenomenon, even: Republican women voted to the left of their male counterparts in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.3 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: ‘Nobody Tells Daddy No’: A Housing Boss’s Many Abuse Cases
description: Victor Rivera gained power and profit as New York’s homeless crisis worsened. Accused of sexual and financial misconduct, he has largely escaped consequences.
content: At first, the offer seemed generous. Erica Sklar was in a homeless shelter and needed a more stable place to live. Victor Rivera, who oversaw a network of shelters, including the one where she was staying, said he had a solution: a spare apartment for her at his home in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Alan Rappeport
title: Democrats to Unveil Up to $3,600 Child Tax Credit as Part of Stimulus Bill
description: The credit would send monthly payments to millions of Americans under certain income thresholds for a year starting in July.
content: WASHINGTON —  Top House Democrats are preparing to unveil legislation that would send up to $3,600 per child to millions of Americans, as lawmakers aim to change the tax code to target child poverty rates as part of President Biden’s sweeping $1.9 trillion stimulus package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make a no-recipe sausage pasta with artichokes, or start setting yourself up for the Super Bowl.
content: Good morning. My friend Gilbert was talking about baguettes the other day, about how the really good ones have this shatteringly crisp crust that can cut the roof of your mouth, and how soft and airy they are within, and how good they smell, and I was suddenly filled with longing and amazement: I haven’t had a good baguette in more than a year. I haven’t had a platter of char siu. I haven’t had a New Jersey bar pizza or a proper lobster roll or a fried grouper sandwich or a slab of hot foie gras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Naomi Levine, Lawyer Who Transformed a University, Dies at 97
description: She thrived in a profession where she found herself mostly surrounded by men, taking on leadership roles and helping turn N.Y.U. into a top-tier institution.
content: Naomi Levine, who as executive director of the American Jewish Congress in the 1970s was the first woman to lead a major Jewish advocacy organization, and who later became an instrumental force in New York University’s transformative expansion into a top-tier institution, died on Jan. 14 at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Wyoming Republicans Censure Liz Cheney for Impeachment Vote
description: The state party voted to censure the No. 3 Republican in the House and demanded her resignation.
content: The Wyoming Republican Party voted on Saturday to censure Representative Liz Cheney, the No. 3 Republican in the House, for her vote last month to impeach Donald J. Trump, underlining the sharp party divisions over breaking with the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: To fight the virus, France relaxes its ban on an American habit: lunch at your desk.
description: PARIS — Eating habits are as good a guide to France as any, and they are about to undergo a radical change.
content: PARIS — Eating habits are as good a guide to France as any, and they are about to undergo a radical change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Without a big aid bill like Biden’s, jobs will be slow to rebound, Yellen warns.
description: The U.S. labor market is stalling and in a “deep hole” that could take years to escape if lawmakers do not quickly pass an aid package that gives workers a bridge to the end of the pandemic, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned on Sunday.
content: The U.S. labor market is stalling and in a “deep hole” that could take years to escape if lawmakers do not quickly pass an aid package that gives workers a bridge to the end of the pandemic, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller, Rebecca Robbins and Lynsey Chutel
title: AstraZeneca’s Vaccine Does Not Work Well Against Virus Variant in South Africa
description: The bad news, coming nearly a week after a million doses of the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine arrived in South Africa, was a big setback for the country.
content: South Africa halted use of the AstraZeneca-Oxford coronavirus vaccine on Sunday after evidence emerged that the vaccine did not protect clinical trial volunteers from mild or moderate illness caused by the more contagious virus variant that was first seen there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: The Working Woman’s Anthem ‘9 to 5’ Needed an Update. But This?
description: A Super Bowl ad has remade Dolly Parton’s feminist classic into an ode to hustle culture. It isn’t quite as empowering as the original.
content: In 1978, when Jane Fonda decided she wanted to make a film about working women, she traveled to Cleveland to meet with members of an organization that would come to be known as 9to5. The women were clerical workers who were fed up with low wages and chauvinist managers, and Ms. Fonda asked them: “Have you ever fantasized about killing your boss?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Protesters rally across Myanmar.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in cities and towns across Myanmar over the weekend, nearly a week after the military took back power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly DiNardo
title: Stay Healthy When Exercising Outdoors
description: Cold weather workouts do bring unique risks, but a little planning and preparation can help whether you’re going for a winter walk, trekking in snowshoes or sledding with the kids.
content: The shift to colder weather makes hibernating under a pile of blankets — perhaps while binge-watching favorite shows — quite tempting. But outdoor exercise is a great way to improve energy levels, boost the immune system, connect with nature and, during the coronavirus pandemic, safely socialize with people outside your bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Through Genetics, Luck or ‘Prehab,’ Tom Brady Endures at 43
description: The mother of the opposing Super Bowl quarterback was a year old when Brady was born. What’s he still doing here?
content: [Follow the Super Bowl live between the Chiefs and Buccaneers.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Big Publishing Pushes Out Trump’s Last Fan
description: Top editors at Hachette have told employees that they’ve learned the lessons of the Capitol siege of Jan. 6: no hate speech, no incitement to violence, no false narratives.
content: If you were a certain kind of distinctly Trumpy public figure — say Donald Trump Jr. or Corey Lewandowski — looking to sell a book over the last four years, there were surprisingly few options. The Big Five publishing companies in New York, and even their dedicated conservative imprints, had become squeamish about the genre known as MAGA books, with its divisive politics and relaxed approach to facts. And small conservative publishers probably couldn’t afford you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller, Rebecca Robbins and Lynsey Chutel
title: South Africa says AstraZeneca’s vaccine doesn’t work well against a variant.
description: South Africa has halted use of the AstraZeneca-Oxford coronavirus vaccine after evidence emerged that the vaccine did not protect clinical-trial participants from mild or moderate illness caused by the more contagious virus variant that was first seen in the country.
content: South Africa has halted use of the AstraZeneca-Oxford coronavirus vaccine after evidence emerged that the vaccine did not protect clinical-trial participants from mild or moderate illness caused by the more contagious virus variant that was first seen in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Glacier Bursts in India, Leaving More Than 100 Missing in Floods
description: Rescue efforts were underway in the northern state of Uttarakhand, where officials said a hydroelectric dam project had been largely swept away.
content: NEW DELHI — A Himalayan glacier broke and caused sudden, massive flooding in the northern Indian state of Uttarakhand on Sunday, smashing two dam projects and forcing the authorities to scramble to evacuate villages and try to save more than 100 lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Schlanger
title: The Mushrooms Will Survive Us
description: In our ruined global moment, watching something busily transform trash into fleshy, sculptural fruit is a comfort.
content: It happened faster than seemed right. One day, the tiny gray pinheads of mushrooms were just beginning to emerge from a two-inch cut in a bag of sawdust; the next, they were huge, scalloped hand-like lobes. They looked practically in motion, like muscular forearms reaching out of a wormhole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: After Abuse Allegations, $2 Billion Shelter Network Faces Scrutiny
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio ordered a review of the groups that run New York’s homeless housing after The New York Times uncovered accusations of sexual and financial misconduct.
content: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio on Sunday ordered a sweeping review of the nonprofit organizations that run the city’s $2 billion network of homeless shelters after allegations emerged that the chief executive of a major operator had used his power to sexually abuse women and enrich himself and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Everything Has a Value’: Afghanistan’s Kidney Trade Preys on the Poor
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 7, 2021.
content: “In Afghanistan everything has a value, except human life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Cindy Nemser, Advocate for Women Artists, Is Dead at 83
description: In the 1970s she called out chauvinism and pushed back against the marginalization of women in the art world, in part by helping to create The Feminist Art Journal.
content: Cindy Nemser, an art critic and historian who, half a century ago, began calling out sexism in the art world, decrying the way women artists were treated and how their work was evaluated, died on Jan. 26 at her home in Brooklyn. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Emil Freireich, Groundbreaking Cancer Researcher, Dies at 93
description: He helped devise a successful chemotherapy regimen for childhood leukemia, which had long been a death sentence.
content: Dr. Emil Freireich, a relentless cancer doctor and researcher who helped devise treatments for childhood leukemia that dramatically transformed the lives of patients thought to have little hope of survival, died on Feb. 1 at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, where he had worked since 1965. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Ron DePasquale
title: The Super Bowl brings fears of another coronavirus surge.
description: Just as the United States seems to have emerged from the worst of a surge in coronavirus cases that ravaged the country for months and peaked after Americans crowded indoors for the winter holidays, public health officials are concerned about another potential superspreader date: Super Bowl Sunday.
content: Just as the United States seems to have emerged from the worst of a surge in coronavirus cases that ravaged the country for months and peaked after Americans crowded indoors for the winter holidays, public health officials are concerned about another potential superspreader date: Super Bowl Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Broadway’s Hair Master Puts Away the Wigs
description: Challenged physically and financially, Paul Huntley, a backstage legend whose artistry is demanded in many a star’s contract, says this show will be his last.
content: Time was when just about every bouffant on Broadway could be traced back to Paul Huntley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 Australian Open: What to Watch on Opening Day
description: Naomi Osaka, Serena Williams and Novak Djokovic are all in action on Rod Laver Arena in Round 1 of the 2021 Australian Open.
content: How to watch: 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Eastern on ESPN and 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. on ESPN2 in the United States; streaming on the ESPN+ app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Why Chuck Schumer Is Cozying Up to the A.O.C. Wing of His Party
description: As he prepares for an impeachment trial this week, Senator Chuck Schumer is at the height of his political power in Washington. At home in New York, he is taking steps to head off a primary challenge from the left.
content: On a recent Sunday evening, about a dozen liberal housing activists from New York gathered for a virtual meeting with Senator Chuck Schumer. Though the newly anointed majority leader had served in Congress for four decades, a number of participants had scarcely interacted with him before, and some regarded him as an uncertain ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Peyton Manning Selected for Pro Football Hall of Fame
description: The selections of Charles Woodson and Calvin Johnson for the Hall of Fame were also announced at the N.F.L. Honors on Saturday. Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers was named the most valuable player.
content: A pair of Aarons pulled off an N.F.L. hat trick Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Where Do Vaccine Doses Go, and Who Gets Them? The Algorithms Decide
description: Health agencies and hospitals are using different formulas to allocate the coronavirus shots, exacerbating disparities in vaccine access.
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: How to handle pandemic fear and stress? For many, the answer is getting married.
description: If the world is ending, who do you want by your side?
content: If the world is ending, who do you want by your side?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morrigan McCarthy
title: Show Your Love With Dried Flowers
description: With lush textures and a smaller carbon footprint than their fresh counterparts, dried floral bouquets have been making a comeback the past few years.
content: When you think of Valentine’s Day traditions, red roses probably top the list, along with a box of chocolates or a meal at a cozy restaurant. But no one needs to be reminded that this year has been anything but traditional. Maybe this Valentine’s Day is a good excuse to lean into the untraditional and try something fresh. Er, not fresh, as the case may be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Breaking With G.O.P., Top Conservative Lawyer Says Trump Can Stand Trial
description: Charles J. Cooper, a stalwart of the conservative legal establishment, said that Republicans were wrong to assert that it is unconstitutional for a former president to be tried for impeachable offenses.
content: One of Washington’s leading conservative constitutional lawyers publicly broke on Sunday with the main Republican argument against convicting former President Donald J. Trump in his impeachment trial, asserting that an ex-president can indeed be tried for high crimes and misdemeanors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Chicago teachers reach a tentative deal with the city to reopen schools.
description: The Chicago Teachers Union has reached a tentative agreement with Mayor Lori Lightfoot to reopen the city’s schools for in-person classes, the mayor announced on Sunday.
content: The Chicago Teachers Union has reached a tentative agreement with Mayor Lori Lightfoot to reopen the city’s schools for in-person classes, the mayor announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: District Attorney Charged in Sexual Assaults on Former Clients
description: Chad Salsman, the elected prosecutor of Bradford County, Pa., was accused of preying on female clients who were in vulnerable legal or personal situations while he was their defense lawyer.
content: The women were targeted because they needed help with child custody cases or criminal charges, prosecutors said. Some had struggled with drug use or were survivors of sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Australian Open Preview: Battle of the Women’s Champions
description: Serena Williams will once again go for her 24th Grand Slam title. Among her competition: three women who won titles in their most recent Grand Slam appearances.
content: Tennis has returned to Melbourne, the site of the last Grand Slam event before the coronavirus pandemic, finding itself both profoundly changed since the last Australian Open and yet eminently recognizable. The top men are still dominating, Serena Williams is still seeking a 24th Grand Slam title, and a growing cast of talented young champions is vying for a sturdy foothold atop the ever-undulating women’s tennis ladder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Lawyer Asks to Pause Impeachment Trial if It Runs Into Sabbath
description: The request by David Schoen, one of former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers, could upend plans for a fast trial.
content: Democrats and Republicans eager to tidily conclude former President Donald J. Trump’s impeachment trial within a week may have a fresh obstacle in front of them: the biblical commandment to keep the Jewish Sabbath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Make a Card, Any Card
description: With your newspaper and some blank card stock, a homemade Valentine or any other greeting is easy to create.
content: There’s nothing like a pretty homemade card to convey your sentiments, whether it’s to express your love, tell someone you miss her or offer belated thanks for a holiday gift. And you don’t need to be an artist to create these easy collaged cards. Cut simple geometric shapes from the newspaper, glue them in a pleasing arrangement and you’re ready to pen your message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: A Longtime Delaware Resident Commutes Home. A Few Things Have Changed.
description: As he had done countless times in his career in public office, Joe Biden returned to the Wilmington suburbs from Washington on Friday — this time, as the commander in chief.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Another workweek had come to an end, and men and women throughout Delaware returned to their homes for a few days away from the office. One of them just happened to be the president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Many Lives of Steven Yeun’
description: What’s a typical immigrant story? In his new film, “Minari,” the “Walking Dead” star has his own to tell.
content: Jay Caspian Kang, the author and narrator of this week’s Sunday Read, spoke with the actor Steven Yeun over Zoom at the end of last year. The premise of their conversations was Mr. Yeun’s latest starring role, in “Minari” — a film about a Korean immigrant family that takes up farming in the rural South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: We Know Very Little About America’s Vaccine Debacle
description: It’s hard to solve a problem when you barely know what’s going on.
content: A few weeks into her part-time job vaccinating nursing home staff members and residents against the coronavirus, Katherine, a pharmacist, noticed a problem: Roughly 15 to 20 vaccines were being thrown away at the end of each vaccination session. That’s because the number of doses that she and her co-workers had prepared — per the protocol established by Katherine’s manager at CVS, the pharmacy she works for — exceeded the number of people who showed up to be inoculated, often significantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Bruce Springsteen and Babies Star in Pandemic-Year Super Bowl Ads
description: Faced with the challenge of promoting products in a difficult time, some companies referenced the nation’s struggles in their marketing messages, while others went for nostalgia.
content: Many viewers who avoided Super Bowl gatherings on Sunday had little else to do but actually pay attention to the dozens of commercials during the breaks in the matchup between Patrick Mahomes of the Kansas City Chiefs and Tom Brady of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Fighting Covid Is Like Fighting a War
description: Why Biden needs to go big and ignore the worriers.
content: There has been some pushback from progressive pundits — most notably Larry Summers, but he’s not alone — against President Biden’s proposal for a very large Covid relief package. Before I get into the reasons I believe this pushback is misguided, let me say that it’s refreshing to discuss good-faith criticism coming from people who actually have some idea what they’re talking about, as opposed to the cynical, know-nothing obstructionism that has become the Republican norm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Kaiser
title: ‘It’s a Sin’: Sex, Adventure and Loss in 1980s London
description: The acclaimed screenwriter Russell T. Davies came of age during London’s AIDS crisis, but this HBO Max mini-series is his first attempt to dramatize it.
content: In 1999, “Queer as Folk” burst into prime time on British television. Overnight, its creator, Russell T. Davies, became his country’s most famous gay writer. The first episode featured a 29-year-old man having sex with a beautiful 15-year-old boy, an image that produced just what Davies wanted: nearly universal outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Top U.S. health experts say vaccine supplies and vaccinations will increase by spring.
description: Officials are racing to vaccinate as many people as possible in order to outpace more contagious variants of the virus that were first identified in Britain and South Africa.
content: Though more contagious variants are spreading in the United States, top health officials sounded notes of optimism on Sunday that both the supply of vaccines and the rate of vaccination will steadily increase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Set Your Alarm to Watch Great Tennis
description: For two weeks starting Sunday, more than 1,000 hours of Australian Open matches will be available to American audiences during the night and into the morning.
content: Depending on your appetite and geographic location, the Australian Open can be the equivalent of a midnight snack or an after-hours all-you-can-eat buffet. Held in Melbourne, Australia, which is 16 hours ahead of the East Coast of the United States, the Grand Slam event is an annual tennis treat for nocturnal American sports fans. This year, more than 1,000 hours of coverage of the singles, doubles and wheelchair competitions will be broadcast in the United States through the night and the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harold Isaac, Andre Paultre and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Haiti Braces for Unrest as a Defiant President Refuses to Step Down
description: Haiti is “on the verge of explosion,” with many accusing the government of supporting gangs to stay in power as a constitutional crisis looms.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The poor now target the poor in Haiti. Many fear leaving their homes, buying groceries or paying a bus fare — acts that can draw the attention of gangs out to kidnap anyone with cash, no matter how little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Impeachment Case Aims to Marshal Outrage of Capitol Attack Against Trump
description: Armed with lessons from the last impeachment trial of Donald J. Trump, prosecutors plan a shorter, video-heavy presentation to confront Republicans with the fury they felt around the Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — When House impeachment managers prosecute former President Donald J. Trump this week for inciting the Capitol attack, they plan to mount a fast-paced, cinematic case aimed at rekindling the outrage lawmakers experienced on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Weiner
title: George P. Shultz, Influential Cabinet Official Under Nixon and Reagan, Dies at 100
description: He carried one of Washington’s weightiest résumés — labor secretary, treasury secretary and budget director for Nixon and secretary of state under Reagan as the Cold War waned.
content: George P. Shultz, who presided with a steady hand over the beginning of the end of the Cold War as President Ronald Reagan’s often embattled secretary of state, died on Saturday at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: For the first time, two women will coach in the Super Bowl. And Sarah Thomas will referee.
description: The 55th Super Bowl will feature a first: Two women will be coaching in the game.
content: The 55th Super Bowl will feature a first: Two women will be coaching in the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: A Holistic View of Vaccine Hesitancy
description: From the perspective of Black people, particularly many young ones, the government is not to be trusted.
content: I recently had a conversation with a younger friend of mine — a Black man in his 30s here in Atlanta — about whether I was going to get the Covid-19 vaccine when it becomes available to me and whether I should.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What It’s Like in Raymond James Stadium
description: This year's Super Bowl is quite a bit different. Here's a look at the scene and the sanitary measures.
content: This year's Super Bowl is quite a bit different. Here's a look at the scene and the sanitary measures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How the Chiefs and Buccaneers Got to the Super Bowl
description: Nearly everyone expected Patrick Mahomes and the Kansas City Chiefs to be back in the Super Bowl. Far fewer people thought Tom Brady, at 43, could take Tampa Bay this far.
content: Nearly everyone expected Patrick Mahomes and the Kansas City Chiefs to be back in the Super Bowl. Far fewer people thought Tom Brady, at 43, could take Tampa Bay this far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times, The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Protests Against Military Takeover Spread Across Myanmar
description: Hundreds of thousands of people flooded the streets of cities across Myanmar on Sunday, demanding an end to military rule a week after the country’s generals took control and detained civilian leaders in a coup.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people flooded the streets of cities across Myanmar on Sunday, demanding an end to military rule a week after the country’s generals took control and detained civilian leaders in a coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 5 Music Podcasts for Kids
description: It’s never too early to start your child’s journey to music aficionado. These audio gems can help.
content: Good news parents, there’s a way to give kids a screen break without forgoing engrossing and educational content. Podcasts, and in particular musical ones, offer a dynamic, attention-grabbing learning opportunity that by their very nature, incite a theater in the minds of little listeners. Below are some hidden gems of musical podcasts that have the potential to teach and delight.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.B.A. Players and the Vaccine
description: A reader says the players’ parents should get the shot first, rather than the players themselves, to avoid an appearance of impropriety. Also: A bipartisan voting commission; women’s philanthropy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Would It Take for Republicans to Convict Trump?
description: “Have they forgotten how they hid under tables and desks fearing for their lives?” a reader asks.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
